awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites: Type II - The Penn I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from the University of Pennsylvania (Penn), extends its I-Corps Site. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. The Penn I-Corps Site supports the translation of research from STEM areas into the marketplace by providing educational programming, financial support, and strategic guidance through offering Site e-teams access to commercialization programs at its innovation hub, the Penn Center for Innovation (PCI). The Site employs a structured process for business model validation following the Lean Launchpad methodology. Within the context of technologies arising from STEM research at Penn, the goals of the Site are to train teams consisting of faculty, staff, and students by providing hands-on experiential entrepreneurial education, and to accelerate startup creation at Penn.

A direct result of the Penn I-Corps Site is hands-on training in the Customer Discover Methodology of faculty and students, applications to the NSF's I-Corp program, validation of market need for team projects, the creation of new startups and, when appropriate, licensing of technologies originating from Penn research. The ultimate goal is to help transition of research to commercialization. Promoting a hands-on experiential approach the Site's activities integrate education and traditional technology transfer. More than 75 teams have already been trained since the Penn Site started operating in the summer of 2015. From these, 32 companies were launched, which have acquired $7.2 million in funding via grant awards and investments, and 39 jobs created.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania

por.por_cntn:
The University of Pennsylvania ("Penn") is a leader among academic institutions in the United States and has one of the country's largest federally funded research programs. It is 4th in the Nation for Research Grants at $1.5 billion in 2020.

In 2011 Penn's the Penn Center of Innovation (PCI) was launched to foster innovation. PCI helps to translate University of Pennsylvania's discoveries and ideas into new products and businesses for the benefit of society. It facilitates technology development connections between Penn and the private sector. Whether the end result is a technology license, an R&D alliance, or the formation of a new venture, PCI serves as a dedicated one-stop-shop for commercial partnering with Penn. In FY2021 PCI Facilitated more than $300 Million of licensing revenue and sponsored research funding combined, and Penn startups raised over $815 Million.

The Penn-Corps Site was established the specific goals of

  1. expand the services that the Penn Center for Innovation (PCI) provides for startup creation in STEM areas to teams involving students;
  2. provide top-of-the-line hands-on experiential entrepreneurial education to 20 teams per year; and
  3. accelerate startup-creation at Penn.
  4. increase efforts to recruit for the National Program;
  5. set clear expectations at the time of team recruitment to ensure teams are a good fit;
  6. follow-up with teams beyond course completion;
  7. calibrate team funding by establishing a grant distribution in tranches; and
  8. increase collaborations and partnerships.

To achieve these goals, Penn I-Corps developed Customer Discovery courses which we refined over the years. Penn I-Corps conducts extensive discovery and recruitment activities, including,

  • annual showcases featuring teams from the program
  •  orientation/networking sessions to aid team formation
  • and development of materials on startup creation services, and
  • customer discovery education.

Since its inception, spanning two NSF I-Corps awards, Penn I-Corps conducted 16 Customer Discovery programs, training 163 teams composed of 403 individuals affiliated with Penn, including 26 faculty, 212 students, and 106 research staff.

Specifically, for this award (award #1829197), spanning 2019 to 2021, we trained 60 teams and 123 participants, including 32 researchers and 90 students.

Beyond course completion, Penn I-Corps continues to support startup formation. We support their participation in other venture creation programs, feature them in PCI outreach activities such as the Celebration of Innovation and PCI's presence at South by South, and connect them with local entrepreneurs and funding sources. To continue their path, Penn I-corps teams participate in programs such as Penn Innovation Prize, YCombinator, DreamIt, Wharton Venture Initiation, and HAX hardware accelerator.

Overall, women make up 30% of Penn I-Corps as participants, mentors, and instructors. Penn I-Corps was one of the members of the I-Corps consortium that conducted a Customer Discovery workshop for minorities at the 2019 BIO Conference.

As a result of the activities supported by the NSF, the I-Corps program has become a signature of innovation and a distinct element of the commercialization support programs Penn offers to faculty and students.  

 

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2022
Modified by: Tomas Isakowitz
